member.name: N:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties
member.summary: Defines the enumerations, property identifiers, and miscellaneous objects that you use with the interfaces defined in the namespace.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.AffinityMode
member.summary: Defines the processor affinity settings that control the association between tasks and cores.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.AffinityMode.AllJobs
member.summary: Directs the HPC Node Manager Service to set the processor affinity for any task to which an entire node is not allocated. This setting is the best choice for jobs such as parameter sweeps and Service-Oriented Architecture (SOA) jobs, for which multiple instances of the application can run per node and for which you want these instances to be isolated from each other. This setting corresponds to the affinity behavior in Windows HPC Server 2008.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.AffinityMode.NoJobs
member.summary: Directs the HPC Node Manager Service never to set processor affinity on any task. This setting is excellent choice if you are running MPI tasks and want to be sure that you can use the –affinity option for the mpiexec command even when jobs share nodes. This setting is also useful for applications that set their own processor affinity. This setting corresponds to the affinity behavior in Windows Compute Cluster Server 2003.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.AffinityMode.NonExclusiveJobs
member.summary: Directs the HPC Node Manager Service not to set affinity on jobs that are marked as exclusive. This setting is the ideal choice for jobs that contain only one task, because this setting enables that task to take advantage of all cores on the nodes to which the task is assigned. This setting provides new affinity-setting behavior for Windows HPC Server 2008 SP1 and is the default setting for Windows HPC Server 2008 SP1, Windows HPC Server 2008 SP2, and Windows HPC Server 2008 R2, because this setting provides the generally preferred behavior for MPI tasks, which are most likely to be sensitive to affinitization. When you use this setting, MPI tasks in exclusive jobs can take advantage of the –affinity option of the mpiexec command even if the task is not allocated an entire node.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.FilterOperator
member.summary: Defines the operators that you can use to compare a property value to a filter value.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.FilterOperator.Equal
member.summary: Include the object in the result if the property value equals the filter value. This enumeration member represents a value of 4.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.FilterOperator.GreaterThan
member.summary: Include the object in the result if the property value is greater than the filter value. This enumeration member represents a value of 0.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.FilterOperator.GreaterThanOrEqual
member.summary: Include the object in the result if the property value is greater than or equal to the filter value. This enumeration member represents a value of 1.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.FilterOperator.HasBitSet
member.summary: Include the object in the result if the property value has one or more bits set. For example, you can use this operator to test if the state of the job is failed or canceled by using the bitwise OR to set the filter value to both states. This enumeration member represents a value of 6.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.FilterOperator.HasExclusiveBitSet
member.summary: Include the object in the result if the property value has a single bit set. This enumeration member represents a value of 10.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.FilterOperator.HasNoBitSet
member.summary: Include the object in the result if the property value has no bits set. This enumeration member represents a value of 7.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.FilterOperator.IsNotNull
member.summary: Include the object in the result if the property value is not null. This enumeration member represents a value of 9.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.FilterOperator.IsNull
member.summary: Include the object in the result if the property value is null. This enumeration member represents a value of 8.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.FilterOperator.LessThan
member.summary: Include the object in the result if the property value is less than the filter value. This enumeration member represents a value of 2.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.FilterOperator.LessThanOrEqual
member.summary: Include the object in the result if the property value is less than or equal to the filter value. This enumeration member represents a value of 3.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.FilterOperator.NotEqual
member.summary: Include the object in the result if the property value is not equal to the filter value. This enumeration member represents a value of 5.

member.summary: A running job can be preempted only after the tasks that are currently running complete. Any remaining tasks in the job will not run. This enumeration member represents a value of 1.

member.summary: A running job can be preempted immediately. This enumeration member represents a value of 2.

member.summary: Running jobs cannot be preempted by higher priority jobs. This enumeration member represents a value of 0.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.PriorityBias
member.summary: Defines how additional resources are allocated to jobs when the scheduling mode is set to .

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.PriorityBias.HighBias
member.summary: Specifies that jobs in a given priority range are given ten times the share of the additional resources than the jobs in the next range below the given priority range. This enumeration member represents a value of 2.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.PriorityBias.MediumBias
member.summary: Specifies that jobs in a given priority range are given twice the share of the additional resources than the jobs in the next range below the given priority range. The priority ranges are Highest, Above Normal, Normal, Below Normal, and Lowest. This value is the default. This enumeration member represents a value of 1.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.PriorityBias.NoBias
member.summary: Specifies that the additional resources are allocated equally across the job queue. This enumeration member represents a value of 0.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.SchedulingMode
member.summary: Defines modes for optimizing resource allocation for large batch and Message Passing Interface (MPI) workloads or for service workloads.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.SchedulingMode.Balanced
member.summary: Specifies that the HPC Job Scheduler Service should attempt to start all incoming jobs as soon as possible at their minimum resource requirements. After all the jobs in the queue have their minimum resources, the HPC Job Scheduler Service should allocate additional cluster resources to jobs based on their priority. The HPC Job Scheduler Service periodically rebalances resource allocation to fill idle resources, start new jobs, and adjust allocation according the setting. This enumeration member represents a value of 1.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.SchedulingMode.Queued
member.summary: Specifies that the HPC Job Scheduler Service should start jobs in queue order, and attempt to allocate the maximum requested resources to running jobs. This enumeration member represents a value of 0.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskState
member.summary: Defines the state of the task.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskState.All
member.summary: A mask used to indicate all states. This enumeration member represents a value of 2047.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskState.Canceled
member.summary: The task was canceled (see ). If the caller provided the reason for canceling the task, then the property will contain the reason. This enumeration member represents a value of 512.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskState.Canceling
member.summary: The task is in the process of being canceled. This enumeration member represents a value of 1024.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskState.Configuring
member.summary: The task is being configured. The application called the method to create the task but has not called the or method to add the task to the job. This enumeration member represents a value of 1.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskState.Dispatching
member.summary: The scheduler is in the process of sending the task to the node to run. This enumeration member represents a value of 16.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskState.Failed
member.summary: The task failed, the job was canceled, or a system error occurred on the compute node. To get a description of the error, access the property. This enumeration member represents a value of 256.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskState.Finished
member.summary: The task successfully finished. This enumeration member represents a value of 128.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskState.Finishing
member.summary: The node is cleaning up the resources that were allocated to the task. This enumeration member represents a value of 64.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskState.NA
member.summary: The state is not set. This enumeration member represents a value of 0.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskState.Queued
member.summary: The task was added to the scheduling queue. This enumeration member represents a value of 8.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskState.Running
member.summary: The task is running. This enumeration member represents a value of 32.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskState.Submitted
member.summary: The task was added to the scheduling queue. This enumeration member represents a value of 2.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskState.Validating
member.summary: The scheduler is determining if the task is correctly configured and can run. This enumeration member represents a value of 4.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskType
member.summary: Defines how to run the command for a task.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskType.Basic
member.summary: Runs a single instance of a serial application or a Message Passing Interface (MPI) application. An MPI application typically runs concurrently on multiple cores and can span multiple nodes. This task type is the default. This enumeration member represents a value of 0.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskType.NodePrep
member.summary: Runs a command or script on each compute node as it is allocated to the job. The Node Prep task runs on a node before any other task in the job. If the Node Prep task fails to run on a node, then that node is not added to the job. This enumeration member represents a value of 2.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskType.NodeRelease
member.summary: Runs a command or script on compute each node as it is released from the job. Node Release tasks run when the job is canceled by the user or by graceful preemption. Node Release tasks do not run when the job is canceled by immediate preemption. This enumeration member represents a value of 3.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskType.ParametricSweep
member.summary: Runs a command a specified number of times as indicated by the start, end, and increment values, generally across indexed input and output files. The steps of the sweep may or may not run in parallel, depending on the resources that are available on the HPC cluster when the task is running. This enumeration member represents a value of 1.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.TaskType.Service
member.summary: Runs a command or service on all resources that are assigned to the job. New instances of the command are started when new resources are added to the job, or if a previously running instance exits and the resource that the previously running instance was running on is still allocated to the job. A service task continues to start new instances until the task is canceled, the maximum run time expires, or the maximum number of instances is reached. A service task can create up to 1,000,000 sub-tasks. Tasks that you submit through a Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) client run as service tasks. You cannot add a basic task or a parametric sweep task to a job that contains a service task. This enumeration member represents a value of 4.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.UserPrivilege
member.summary: Indicates to which group the user belongs.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.UserPrivilege.AccessDenied
member.summary: The user has no access privileges (the user does not belong to the Administrators group or Users group). This enumeration member represents a value of 0.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.UserPrivilege.Admin
member.summary: The user belongs to the Administrators group on the head node. This enumeration member represents a value of 2.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Hpc.Scheduler.Properties.UserPrivilege.User
member.summary: The user belongs to the Users group on the head node. This enumeration member represents a value of 1.
